data.title: Bulk Enable/Disable packages based on programming language they belong to
data.body: Now that atom can help with so many languages, the list of packages that I have with it has grown too long. This makes the packages menu options go beyond the screen. It would be great if there was an option to group a bunch of packages and be able to enable/disable them in bulk. This would make sure that while I working on Java or Javascript, the packages for python or ruby remain disabled.

data.title: Atom Helper Daemons consuming too much RAM
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

Atom creates multiple Helper daemons on startup, each taking up 150+ MB of RAM, causing my system to slow down and sometimes even hang, despite having 6 GB. Of course, the expectation is that I run other applications on my laptop as well.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Run Atom
2. Check the Activity Monitor for RAM usage of the Helpers.

**Expected behavior:** Atom runs smoothly.

**Actual behavior:** Atom eats up all my RAM and hangs.
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

Atom : 1.6.2
Mac OSX: 10.10.5

data.title: dialog boxes
data.body: to improve speed and efficiency and continuity, dialog boxes such as those in which a user is prompted to delete a file should have standard Yes or No options which are accessible via the keyboard. This reduces time as the user does not have to click nor alter hand placement nor use multiple keys to accomplish this task. It also improves continuity in that much of Atom is currently designed for ease and maneuverability via simple keys and key combinations. Lastly it is more efficient in that it requires less work to physically achieve this goal emphasized by the speed/work ratio.

data.title: Fixed positioning for overlay
data.body:
This PR changes the positioning of the overlay from absolute to fixed.
This ensures that no overflow will be triggered in surrounding elements, which is important especially for mini TextEditors.
cc @nathansobo

data.title: :memo: Fix linking the decorateMarker
data.body:
Error happens at this place in the docs
https://atom.io/docs/api/v1.6.2/TextEditor#instance-decorateMarkerLayer

data.title: :memo: Add the --no-install flag to the windows build readme
data.body:
``` diff
 +  * `--no-install` - Skips the installation task after building.
```

data.title: Application shortcut removed each time installing Atom on Windows
data.body:
### Description

It's just a small issue but it seems, as if each time in Update Atom, any existing shortcuts to Atom get removed or are no longer valid.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Install Atom
2. Create a shortcut based on the newly created Atom icon
3. Update Atom the the Shortcut is gone
### Versions

Windows 7 x64
All the way up to Atom 1.6.2

data.title: Rendering freezes when snapping window in Windows 10
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

The editor view freezes when snapping the editor window to either side of the screen in Windows 10.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Start Atom.
2. Snap Atom to one side of the screen by dragging its titlebar to the edge of the screen.

**Expected behavior:** Atom should snap to the side and continue to function as usual.

**Actual behavior:** The cursor disappears and the editor view is not updated until the window is maximized.
### Versions

Windows 10.0.10586
Atom 1.6.2
apm 1.6.0
npm 2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 3.5.1

data.title: Use display layers facility of text-buffer; delete all the code they replace
data.body: This PR replaces a bunch of old and twisty code in `TextEditor` with usage of a new facility in the `text-buffer` library introduced in https://github.com/atom/text-buffer/pull/149. You can read that pull request for more information about what replaces all the code we're deleting here.

data.title: Added .apm to .gitignore
data.body: Based on comment in dot-atom/.apm/.apmrc, the .apm directory created as part of the default startup is a cache, therefore it shouldn't be included in git.

data.title: Signing support on Windows with P12 keys
data.body:
Allows signing of the Windows executables (atom.exe, update.exe, atomsetup.exe) using the standard Windows SDK signing tool. 

Included is a test signing pfx/p12 signing key with the password 'password'. You can specify your own using the WIN_P12KEY_PASSWORD and WIN_P12KEY_URL as the Atom team will do on official builds when signing with the official key.

data.title: Atom Startup: It rarely starts.
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [Y] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [Y] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [Y] Did you check the [debugging guide](flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [Y] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [Y] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [Y] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

Atom keeps showing these two messages when I open my project. Even starting with --safe mode _at least_ shows those errors once or twice.

![1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/760112/14395989/a89987f4-fdf2-11e5-8845-150b6e83fede.png)
![2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/760112/14395988/a8998204-fdf2-11e5-8aa8-66292e7de802.png)

This is happening with the latest version of atom also (I can remember it happening significant number of times since 1.6.0). My project is about 1100 files in the `src` folder. It also has `node_modules`, `webpack` temp files, etc, but they are already in the ignore list.

I suspect it's due to the tree-view plugin, which causes atom to lock up every now and then when I expand/collapse a folder, and generally makes atom very sluggish.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open a project with 1000+ files in atom
2. Wait forever to edit
3. ![2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/760112/14395988/a8998204-fdf2-11e5-8aa8-66292e7de802.png)
4. Click **Close Window** and try again.

**Expected behavior:** Atom shouldn't freeze so much.

**Actual behavior:** Sublime works smoothly. Atom should atleast let me edit the files.
### Versions

Version: 1.6.2 (1.6.0+)
OS: Windows 10 x64

data.title: Use #index instead of #openIndex.
data.body: # openIndex is going away: https://github.com/nodegit/nodegit/pull/989

data.title: Using the treefile "New file" in a keyboard shortcut, it's really powerful
data.body:
Instead of using the cmd + n (to open new file) and cmd + s (to save for the first time). It'd be great to just have a shortcut to use the right click in treefile "New File", It even makes folders wich is awesome.

![](http://i.imgur.com/Go39q4a.gif?1)

Sorry for bad gif, but I'm totally new and yes it was intended to show the whole tree

hello/world/itsa/me/mario.me

data.title: Package serialize function gets called on click in editor - 1.7 beta
data.body:
### Description

In 1.7 beta, it seems like the serialize function for every active package gets called when a text editor is clicked.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Have a package installed that has a serialize function.
2. Put a console.log in the serialize function
3. Notice that the console.log is called every time that an editor is clicked.

**Expected behavior:** I am not sure, but I would think that serialize would behave like 1.6.

**Actual behavior:** Serialize function is called way too often I believe.
### Versions

1.7 beta on both Windows 10 and Mac OSX Yosemite

data.title: Data loss after power outage
data.body:
### Description

How to restore corrupted file after power outage.

This has happened three times in the past half year and now really disappointed (to say the least, sorry). But this is not the behaviour I expect from a quality editor. Cannot find via Google or issues in GitHub how to resolve this.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Edit a file
2. Laptop runs out of battery power
3. Power laptop and restart system
4. Open file which is now corrupted and looking like �6G�-���L����T�T�8L��s#]�Ϩ���8L��s#]�Ϩ��� etc

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

That the file is never corrupted after a power cycle or the corrupted file is restorable. An editort should **never** be alowed to have this behaviour. At the moment of the power cycle I was not saving, only typing.

Is there any tool to run and get my original file back?

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

I ended up with a corrupted file as described above.
### Versions

Up to date Ubuntu 15.10 with
$ atom --version
1.6.2
$ apm --version
apm  1.6.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
git 2.5.0

data.title: Atom broke when opening file with sudo ubuntu 15.04
data.body:
Running this command in the terminal:
`jorgen@jorgen-pc:~/hadoop-2.7.0/etc/hadoop$ sudo atom hadoop-env.sh 
`

This error is displayed inside of the atom window (The web developer tools opens inside of atom and produces this message):

```

data.title: Fix dead atom.io/docs links in CONTRIBUTING.md
data.body:
This file wasn't updated for the flight-manual conversion.

I also fixed two `https://atom.io/docs/latest` URLs, one of which was inadvertently going to the Notifications API when it was talking about core, and the other leading to a 404.

Would love some :eyeglasses: in case I missed anything!  /cc @atom/feedback

data.title: Uncaught Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, close
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x ] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [ ] Did you check the [debugging guide](flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [ ] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [ ] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x ] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

-- I had updated another bug which looked similar to me (10774), but was asked to open a new issue.
### Description

While trying to save a file, which was moved from one directory to another, saw this error.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Create a file in a directory and open it for editing
2. While the file is open, go to the terminal and move the file to another directory
3. In Atom, open this file in a new tab and then try to save..see the "ENOENT..." error

Notes:
1. The file does seem to get saved.
2. I am working on a directory which is mounted remotely.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

MacBook-Pro:ha uvanzara$ atom --version
1.6.2
MacBook-Pro:ha uvanzara$ apm --version
apm  1.6.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
git 2.6.4

[Enter steps to reproduce below:]
1. ...
2. ...

**Atom Version**: 1.6.2
**System**: Mac OS X 10.11.4
**Thrown From**: Atom Core
### Stack Trace

Uncaught Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, close

```

    at Object.fs.writeFileSync (fs.js:1188:8)
    at Object.fsPlus.writeFileSync (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/fs-plus/lib/fs-plus.js:279:17)
    at File.module.exports.File.writeFileSync (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/pathwatcher/lib/file.js:282:19)

    at File.module.exports.File.writeSync (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/pathwatcher/lib/file.js:355:12)

data.title: Update nodegit to 0.12.2
data.body:
This should add support for 32-bit Linux systems (nodegit 0.12.2 now has prebuilt binaries for it)

(I don't have a 32-bit Linux system with me right now to test this, unfortunately, but I know that the 32-bit binary exists, as I was able to manually download it and make sure it was a 32-bit binary)

Related: #10819

data.title: Problem displaying Chinese
data.body:
### Description

Normally my Atom has no problem displaying Chinese. But when I open this file http://w.nycweb.io/luanma.txt all Chinese characters are messed up.
### Steps to Reproduce

The file is originally a .html file. I copy some contents from a [webpage](http://blog.sina.com.cn/s/blog_6175bf700102wbc1.html) and paste it to WORD, then save as this html file. Notepad++ and Notepad have no problem displaying Chinese characters in it.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
This is what Notepad++ displays:
![normal](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12814040/14370253/7f5304ae-fcfa-11e5-9ad2-bc474dcf62d7.png)

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
And this is what Atom displays:
![atom](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12814040/14370267/aab7ed8a-fcfa-11e5-94fb-978a569aa3e8.png)
### Versions

1.6.2@windows 10

I think this has something to do with the redundant html codes generated by WORD, but why does the codes affect how atom displays UTF-8 characters?

data.title: Package URL handlers - mapping atom:// URIs to package functions
data.body:
See update below: https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/11399#issuecomment-330396536

---

This PR implements the `MessageRegistry`, which is similar to the `CommandRegistry` in that it maps string types of some kind to callback functions, but it differs in that messages originate from outside the application via `atom://` URIs handled via [the `open-url` event](http://electron.atom.io/docs/v0.37.4/api/app/#event-open-url-os-x).

This partially implements https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/5262, provides a mechanism for hitting things like https://github.com/atom/settings-view/pull/614 from outside the application (e.g. "View in Atom" links on package pages on the Atom site), and would enable package authors to implement things like https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/2037 for external debuggers, etc.

There is still some additional work to do around registering Atom as a system-level handler for `atom://` URIs on non-Mac systems, but that probably will be installer-based work.

/cc @atom/core @atom/feedback for review. Some open questions I have are:
- I restricted messages to URIs starting with `atom://atom` as we already [have a mechanism that utilizes URIs with hosts that match package names](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/822e0c95108aadb91631570e386d8cf96d7cfdd0/src/browser/atom-application.coffee#L550-L557) to perform some work. (What is this used for? I'm not familiar with it.) I'd love to get rid of this, as it means we can't use any host that might match a package name. If anyone has bright ideas for URI schemes, that'd be awesome. (I thought maybe something like `atom://.message/...`?)
- Right now, the callback function is called with the string message (just the `namespace:name` portion) and the params, but maybe it makes more sense to pass the entire URI, or the parsed URI object.
